text: True. And certainly there were people whose fight for the CSA was predicated on that, esp. after Lincoln called for the militia to put down rebellion in S.C. But the South's political elite was intent on forming a slaveholding empire unmoored from America's founding ideals.

text: Eh, that kinda falls under my lame-name category. No offense. It's just meh. Replace one historical figure with another. If not Ellsworth, idk, maybe a Virginian who fought with valor for the Union. Find some obscure soldier who fits that category and go for it.

text: But certainly most rabid secessionists in the Southern political elite were the antithesis of the founding ethos of our Republic. They were itching to form a slaveholding empire unmoored from our founding ideal that all men are created equal, endowed by our Creator with rights

text: I use traitor here in a moral sense, not a legal one. I'd actually argue those who resigned from government and left its service out of conviction were not technically traitors. Misguided, wrong, but not traitors, given that question of secession was as yet untested.

author: KenShepherd

text: ymmv from congregation to congregation, I'll grant. And I give Columbia Pres props for prominently listing your elders and deacons as well as your staff.
author: KenShepherd

text: And it does seem to ape non-denom megachurch templates of leadership than a confessionally Presbyterian one, accordingly. That I think is CW's and Todd's concern and I find it a valid concern.
author: KenShepherd

text: Some church websites give you the impression the staff members are essentially the church leadership and the session is kind of likes its board of directors. A nice honorary gig but not really essential to its governance on a practical level.
author: KenShepherd

text: It communicates the staff guys are the guys you wanna talk to if you have questions or concerns. Which, sometimes, sure. But as goes the actual governing of the church, that's the province of the elders. So why not communicate that better?
author: KenShepherd

text: Sometimes, sure. But since the elders shepherd the church and the diaconate cares for its physical needs, surely it's a good idea to highlight on the website the men called by God to serve that local congregation in that capacity, no?
author: KenShepherd

text: The notion that our rights are derived from our Creator, that's just basic American political philosophy 101. It's literally in our nation's basic law via our Declaration of Independence. It's our heritage as Americans and one we should preserve.
author: KenShepherd

text: Far from being the height of human conceit, the notion of natural/God-given rights is supposed to reflect our humility as human beings in the grand scheme of things. Our dignity derives from a greater source, not our exercise of raw political power. But you do you.
author: KenShepherd

text: ... it's not very helpful for a Presbyterian church to downplay the centrality of this feature of our (eminently biblical) church polity.
author: KenShepherd

text: Obviously churches of any size will need some staff, particularly for administrative tasks (secretary, handling bookkeeping, etc.), and they should be properly compensated and valued. But the care and govt. of the church is entrusted to elders, diaconate and accordingly...
author: KenShepherd

text: Not very analogous. Correspondence greeting the saints in the Lord is hardly similar to a website that effectively communicates that paid staff, not ordained elders and deacons, are those who shepherd and attend the physical needs of church respectively.

text:
Bill Clinton never won an outright majority of the popular vote. Came close in 1996 with 49.6% of the NPV. Hillary got 48.2% NPV in 2016.

Obama is our last POTUS to win more than 50%, which he did twice.
author: KenShepherd

text: But as I said, if your beef with EC is "undemocratic," it seems undemocratic to me to reform the election but have it so a non-majority-garnering pol ascends to the White House.
author: KenShepherd

text: They have runoffs all the time. Course it's a jungle primary in November with all the parties running together. But still, you don't get 50% there you have to win in a runoff.

text: But I'll climb down off my soapbox now. I'm very skeptical of government actors promising us increased safety if we just surrender our liberties. It diminishes us as citizens and moral agents and empowers the Leviathan of government.

text: Heck, look at Aussie PM Morrison sounding out further regulation of social media. Fraught with peril if you're going to regulate content of speech, but, here we are, all because a crisis must not go wasted.

text: Yes. And a bad actor's abuse of a right is not proper license to remove that right from those who will never abuse it.
author: KenShepherd

text: And yes, there are many cases of particularly vulnerable, physically weaker individuals using say an AR-15 to stop a home invasion robbery or the like. 5'2", 130-lb woman vs a few loked out home invaders, no match physically. With proper firepower...

text: I'm not frightened of anything. But it's prudent to have a weapon that has a little bit of margin for error when used in a high-stress situation like a home invasion burglary, and, tbh, a good semiauto handgun or rifle is helpful there.

text: Sport shooting is a fun, relaxing pastime, for one. That and clay shooting sports, though for that you use shotguns. Although I am dreadfully bad at trap and skeet.
author: KenShepherd

text: I'm not even the biggest gun guy out there, to be honest. I own one firearm, a Glock semiautomatic pistol. I might, someday buy a tactical shotgun for the house. I personally don't feel compelled to buy a semiauto rifle anytime soon but it's my right to do so.
author: KenShepherd

text: But political rights aren't predicated on need, are they? Do you need a library of more than say 30 books? Why should you be trusted to read books that has literally set the world ablaze, like Mao's Little Red Book, Hitler's Mein Kampf.
author: KenShepherd

text: It's part of the tradition of Anglo-American political liberty that sadly has been abandoned by all but Americans.
author: KenShepherd

text: Also I rather trust the civilian populace with so-called military-style semiautomatic rifles. They are perfectly sensible for home defense and they're great for sport shooting.
author: KenShepherd

text: Not all semi-autos are "military style" and military-style is a rather amorphous term that is more PR than technical.
author: KenShepherd

text: I'm not against loathing some people after they're dead, but that category I reserve to brutal thugs like Osama bin Laden, Pol Pot, Stalin, Lenin, Che Guevara, Mao, et al. Oh, and whatever asshole invented Brutalist architecture.

text: And regardless of where you stand on gun rights, surely it should trouble you when legislative action fundamentally affecting the rights and privileges of civilians is taken in a matter of days, implemented immediately. That is hardly wise parliamentary deliberation, surely.
author: KenShepherd

text: To abrogate that and punish peaceful civilians for the murderous acts of a terrorist is to treat to the civilian gun-owning population as serfs who may be bossed about by the lord of the manor (the country's elected officials) rather than citizens with rights to be protected.
author: KenShepherd

text: The peaceful civilian ownership of means of defense for self and the commonwealth is a cornerstone of liberal democracy and also, I'd argue, a natural right connected to our natural right to defense of self, family, and home.

Got a news release from Tubi about what's coming in April. They led with <<  "The Bachelor," "The Bachelorette," "Donnie Darko," ...>> in the email subject line but really buried the lede, I think. 

Also coming in April: the cinematic triumph that was 1998's "Species II"
author: KenShepherd

text: Kiwis have a significantly lower per capita homicide rate than the UK, which has much more stringent laws against civilian firearms ownership.

text: Good stuff. I got the Nashville hot chicken sandwich. To be on the safe side I went with the mildest option thereof. Next time I'll kick it up to medium hotness. Got mac 'n cheese and a drink with it. Mac was only aight. Next time will try the fries.

text: Maybe so. In a moral sense, though, if you genuinely feel that the president's use of emergency declaration is a threat to the constitutional order, you're duty bound to your oath of office to vote accordingly, imo.

text: It is telling that some Dems want 16 to vote but 21 to own any gun. So five years to be voting for pols who limit our liberties before you can exercise a fundamental and constitutional right. Wut.
